mechanism_of_action.References: Osol, A. and J.E. Hoover, et al. (eds.). Remington's Pharmaceutical Sciences. 15th ed. Easton, Pennsylvania: Mack Publishing Co., 1975., p. 1244
mechanism_of_action.Value: TAKEN WITH 1 OR 2 GLASSFUL OF WATER, IT FORMS COLLOIDAL SOLN IN UPPER ALIMENTARY TRACT; THIS SOLN LOSES WATER IN COLON, TO FORM GEL WHICH INCR BULK & SOFTNESS OF STOOL.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Clayton, G.D., F.E. Clayton (eds.) Patty's Industrial Hygiene and Toxicology. Volumes 2A, 2B, 2C, 2D, 2E, 2F: Toxicology. 4th ed. New York, NY: John Wiley & Sons Inc., 1993-1994., p. 511
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: Low viscosity (15 cP) methylcellulose /admin/ iv to dogs produced serious ... necrotizing vascular disease was frequently observed and death was generally due to renal failure.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Clayton, G.D., F.E. Clayton (eds.) Patty's Industrial Hygiene and Toxicology. Volumes 2A, 2B, 2C, 2D, 2E, 2F: Toxicology. 4th ed. New York, NY: John Wiley & Sons Inc., 1993-1994., p. 511
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: Groups of rats were injected ip with methyl cellulose (400 cP) twice weekly for 15 weeks. Animals observations were made of grossly enlarged spleens, changes in the bone marrow and cellular elements of the blood, ascites, and infiltration of the spleen, liver, and kidneys with "storage-cell" macrophages.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Clayton, G.D., F.E. Clayton (eds.) Patty's Industrial Hygiene and Toxicology. Volumes 2A, 2B, 2C, 2D, 2E, 2F: Toxicology. 4th ed. New York, NY: John Wiley & Sons Inc., 1993-1994., p. 511
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /Researchers/ repeatedly admin low viscosity (15 cP) methyl cellulose intravenously to dogs and observed serious effects characterized by a progressive decrease in the volume of urine and the presence in the urine of albumin, casts, and both red and white blood cells. Nonprotein nitrogen levels of blood rose sharply but blood pressure was not increased.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Lefaux, R. Practical Toxicology of Plastics. Cleveland: CRC Press Inc., 1968., p. 282
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: METHYL CELLULOSE IS ARTIFICIAL HIGH POLYMER & IV INJECTIONS OF IT HAVE BEEN TRIED OUT ON DOGS... IT WAS SHOWN THAT REPEATED SMALL DOSES GAVE RISE TO KIDNEY LESIONS SIMILAR TO THOSE FOUND IN GLOMERULAR NEPHRITIS. ...CANNOT BE USED AS PLASMA SUBSTITUTE.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Gosselin, R.E., H.C. Hodge, R.P. Smith, and M.N. Gleason. Clinical Toxicology of Commercial Products. 4th ed. Baltimore: Williams and Wilkins, 1976., p. II-167
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: GIVEN PARENTERALLY, HOWEVER, METHYL CELLULOSE PRODUCES GLOMERULONEPHRITIS & HYPERTENSION IN RATS.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Lefaux, R. Practical Toxicology of Plastics. Cleveland: CRC Press Inc., 1968., p. 282
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: ...WHEN...INJECTED INTO RAT IT ULTIMATELY GIVES RISE TO CARDIOVASCULAR TROUBLES...

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: American Medical Association, AMA Department of Drugs, AMA Drug Evaluations. 3rd ed. Littleton, Massachusetts: PSG Publishing Co., Inc., 1977., p. 487
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: BULK FILLERS (EG, METHYLCELLULOSE) HAVE BEEN SHOWN IN ANIMALS TO HAVE ONLY TRANSIENT ANORECTIC EFFECT.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Grant, W.M. Toxicology of the Eye. 3rd ed. Springfield, IL: Charles C. Thomas Publisher, 1986., p. 611
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: Injected into the anterior chamber of rabbits, 0.1 ml of 0.5-1% methyl cellulose in 0.9% sodium chloride soln causes mild iridocyclitis ... in balanced salt soln ... causes no clinically evident reaction. ... when AQ humor is replaced by 0.5% methyl cellulose in rabbit intraocular pressure may rise to 60 mm Hg during next hr or 2.
